Body.Content:
Introduction

To help Security Operations Center (SOC) teams reduce alert noise and optimize incident queues, Microsoft is introducing new built-in alert tuning rules in Microsoft Defender XDR. This configuration change is designed to streamline alert handling by automatically suppressing low-priority alerts and surfacing only those that require SOC action. These changes reflect ongoing feedback from customers seeking greater efficiency in incident triage.

When this will happen:
  • October 19, 2025: New alert tuning experience becomes visible in the UX. Functionality is not yet active.
  • October 19â€“29, 2025: Opt-out window. Admins can choose to disable auto-suppression.
  • October 30, 2025: Functionality goes live. Auto-suppression is enabled by default.
How this affects your organization:
  • Who is affected: Preview participants using Microsoft Defender XDR, particularly those with Defender for Office (MDO) alerts.
  • What will happen:
    • New built-in alert tuning rules will appear in the UX starting October 19.
    • Auto-suppression will be enabled by default starting October 30.
    • Selected alerts with available AIR playbooks will be created in the Resolved state and assigned to Suppression rule.
    • AIR will investigate these alerts immediately:
      • If remediation is successful, alerts remain Resolved.
      • If pending actions remain or manual review is needed, alerts will reopen automatically as New and Unassigned.
    • Only alerts requiring SOC action will appear as Open.
    • Admins can disable auto-suppression at any time in Alert Tuning.
What you can do to prepare:
  • No action is required if you want to benefit from reduced alert noise and improved SOC efficiency.
  • If your Security Operations Center prefers to manually review every alert regardless of AIR outcome, complete the following before October 30:
    • Review the new alert tuning settings in the UX.
    • Decide whether to opt out of auto-suppression.
    • Communicate this change to SOC and helpdesk teams.
    • Update internal documentation if needed.
    • To opt out, go to Alert Tuning in the portal and disable auto-suppression.
Compliance considerations
QuestionExplanation
Does the change alter how existing customer data is processed, stored, or accessed?Alerts are now auto-suppressed and AIR playbooks may resolve them without manual SOC review, changing how alert data is surfaced and acted upon.
Does the change introduce or significantly modify AI/ML or agent capabilities that interact with or provide access to customer data?AIR playbooks will automatically investigate and remediate alerts, modifying alert state based on AIR investigations.
Does the change include an admin control and can it be controlled through Entra ID group membership?Admins can disable auto-suppression via Alert Tuning. 
Does the change allow a user to enable and disable the feature themselves?Admins can opt out during the opt-out window or disable auto-suppression at any time.

Details.Name: Summary
Details.Value: Microsoft Defender XDR will introduce built-in alert tuning rules by October 30, 2025, to auto-suppress low-priority alerts, reducing noise and optimizing SOC incident queues. Admins can opt out or disable this feature anytime. Alerts may be auto-resolved or reopened based on AIR playbook investigations.

Title: [Configuration Change] New Built-in Alert Tuning Rules to optimize incident and alert queues
